DOC.TEXT: Prices moved marginally higher in extremely light trading on Wall Street today with bargain-hunting responsible for the gains. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 7.68 at 2,719.07 as of 2 p.m. EST after have been down about seven points in earlier trading. The broader market was also slightly higher. Advancing issues were ahead of decliners by a margin of about 10 to 9, with 701 stocks rising, 626 falling and 532 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to a light 53.64 million shares with two hours of trading left. Many traders were extending their Christmas holiday into this week. Stocks declined early in the session as bond prices slumped in response to an increase Monday in Japan's discount rate from 3.75 percent to 4.25 percent. The Treasury's 30-year bond was down about } point, or $6.25 per $1,000 in face amount, while its yield rose to 7.95 from 7.88 late Friday. Analysts said some of the drop in bonds also was attributable to traders adjusting yearend portfolios and to concerns about inflation. Prices for heating oil and orange juice futures rose sharply today because of the cold weather, and traders speculated that inflation might accelerate. But as the session progressed on Wall Street, traders decided that there was little cause for concern, said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. Investors had available cash and were in the market picking up bargains, Metz said. The most-actively traded stock on the NYSE was Bank of New England, which rose ] to 7~. Exxon was down \ to 50] after a weekend explosion shut down a major refinery in Texas. American Express was up 1 to 32~, IBM was off ] to 95 and Sears, Roebuck was up | to 37]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.22 to 192.17. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.15 to 370.99.
